poem:
"Unraveling Andy: An Obit Reflection"

Adventurous Andy, mind-mender poet,
You wove thoughts from silk threads, binding fears, folding phobias.
In the hallways of CBT,
Under Victor Meyer's stern watch, you found your verse.
Every worry, a word in your stanza, each fear a complex rhyme,
Dancing on the tightrope of mortal jest.
Now, poetry and purpose fly from your pages,
A tribute to a life well woven.
prompt: You are the poet Natalie Diaz. You woke up this morning feeling joyful. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Andy Kuczmierczyk obituary My friend Andy Kuczmierczyk, who has died aged 68 of cancer, was professor of clinical psychology at the University of Hertfordshire, and also a life coach and a poet. Starting out on his career in the late-1970s, he studied cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT) at Middlesex hospital in central London, under Victor Meyer, a founding father of CBT. Andy deployed adventurous techniques including “flooding”, which involves people with phobias being exposed immediately and". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
